chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: To use the plugin, first start it from Plugins menu or open up the Console dockable and select the LuaJ-SE shell (LuaJ - Scripting Engine). Once selected, it will attempt to start up the Read-Eval-Print-Loop, and if successful, the LuaJ-SE prompt will be displayed. If not successful, the LuaJ plugin may need to be configured. Refer to that plugin's documentation for information on how to configure it.

The LuaJ-SE Shell plugin adds to jEdit the LuaJ script handler so you can write macros and startup scripts in LuaJ. The console interface to the LuaJ script engine shell can be useful for creating and testing jEdit macros in LuaJ.

chapter.title: Evaluating Code
chapter.para: The easiest way to evaluate code in the shell is to simply type it in and hit enter. There are several actions available that make it easier to test a portion of your code without having to manually copy and paste it.

These actions can be found in the menu Plugins -> LuaJ-SE Shell. Using these actions, you can use the shell to evaluate the active buffer, any selected text within that buffer, or an external LuaJ script.
Any variables or functions defined in the shell will persist until the loop is terminated.

chapter.title: Global Variables
chapter.para:
LuaJ-SE Shell Plugin provides the same global variables as the JavaScriptShell Plugin.
view - the current jEdit view
editPane - the current jEdit editPane
textArea - the current jEdit textArea
buffer - the current jEdit buffer
wm - the dockableWindowManager of the curre
scriptPath - the path of the script in the current buffer
console - console
output - output
engine - LuaJ scripting engine

chapter.title: Macros and Scripting
chapter.para: jEdit macros in LuaJ are LuaJ scripts with file name extension lua, placed in the jEdit's settings or home subdirectory /macros. Macros are visible in the Macros menu when LuaJ-SE Shell plugin is started and macros are rescanned (in Macros menu).

The following code can be saved as a sample macro in LuaJ:
view:splitHorizontally()
After the LuaJ-SE Shell plugin is started, via the plugin's menu item Load startup script(s) one can load so-called start-up script(s) where some handy functions are collected.
